content.description: An experiment was designed to investigate the relationship between the dosage of a certain migraine medication and the amount of time until relief from the headache was experienced. Four dosages in milligrams (<math alttext="m g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>)—<math alttext="2.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="5.0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5.0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="7.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>—of the medication were used. The <math alttext="20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> participants in the experiment were known to experience migraines. Each participant was randomly assigned one of the four dosages. When the participants experienced a migraine, they took the assigned medication and recorded the number of minutes it took to experience relief from the headache. The mean number of minutes it took each group to experience relief was compared.
content.question: What were the experimental units in the experiment?

choices.label: The number of minutes to experience relief
The mean number of minutes it took each group to experience relief
The relationship between the dosage and the amount of time

skill.text: Skill 1.B: Identify key and relevant information to answer a question or solve a problem.
